EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The Ispat Inland (Ispat) Indiana Harbor Works facility is an iron and steel manufacturer located in Lake County in Northwest Indiana on the shore of Lake Michigan.  The Ispat site occupies approximately 2,200 acres.

Operations at the site began on July, 21, 1902.  The primary processes include the production of iron in blast furnaces and steel in Basic Oxygen Furnace (BOF) processes and Electric Arc Furnace (EAF) melting.  Finishing operations at the facility include the operation of blooming mills, bar mills, hot strip mill, temper mills, annealing furnaces, and coating, cutting and shearing operations.  Support facilities include power generation plants, recycle and waste recovery operations, and wastewater treatment.

The facility is bounded to the west by the Indiana Harbor Ship Canal and Lake Michigan; to the north and east by Lake Michigan; and to the south and southeast by industrial property and Highway 912.  Land use in the vicinity of the Ispat site is a combination of industrial. Commercial, residential and recreational areas.

The Ispat site operates under the following General Environmental Policy (III-ENV-001, 8/30/01).  "It is the policy of Ispat Inland Inc. to be in compliance with environmental laws and regulations and other requirements, to pursue continuous improvement in environmental performance, and to practice pollution prevention for our operations and activities.  We will annually review targets and objectives that drive continuous improvement in our environmental performance."

At the Ispat site, chlorine is stored in 2,000 pound cylinders and is used for water treatment as a 1) biocide for slime control in process equipment, and 2) growth inhibitor for zebra mussels.  The storage and transfer (metering into the wastewater treatment systems) process is subject to both the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management regulations and the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Chemical Accid

ent Prevention (RMP) regulations.

ACCIDENT PREVENTION

In order to prevent accidents, Ispat personnel have implemented a comprehensive safety program that incorporates multiple layers of safety.  Those layers of safety involve engineering controls, operating practices and management review.  The following summarizes the layers of safety in place at Ispat:

LAYERS OF SAFETY

Process and Technology - a) rigorous compliance with standards (including Process Safety Management) and codes,  b) structured hazard analysis, and c) comprehensive preventive maintenance.

Safety and People - a) documented operating procedures,  b) ongoing employee training,  c) strict contractor rules, and d) employee participation.

Management and Support Program -  a) management of change,  b) incident investigation, and c) periodic compliance audits.


FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY - Ispat Inland has experienced no reportable accidents in the Five-Year Accident History.


EMERGENCY REPONSE MEASURES

Ispat personnel have developed a sophisticated emergency response capability.  The fundamentals of the emergency response program are early detection, prompt effective communications, and source control.  The elements of the emergency reponse program for chlorine include:  a) chlorine leak sensors linked to alarms,  b) 24-hour monitoring of alarms,  c) documented communication/reporting procedures,  d) trained emergency reponse team on-site,  and  e) extensive emergency reponse equipment maintained on-site.
